title: Quiz 2: Surgery FQE (Feb 2024)
description: Surgery Final Qualifying Examination from February 2024. Covers General Surgery, Orthopaedics, Trauma, and Urology scenarios.

questions.question: A patient presents with a 4-hour history of painful swelling on his right gluteal region. Diagnosis: Gluteal abscess. What is the correct treatment?
questions.explanation: The definitive treatment for an abscess is drainage of the pus ('Ubi pus, ibi evacua'). Antibiotics alone cannot penetrate the cavity effectively.
questions.hint: Where there is pus, let it out.

questions.question: Categorize the principles of fracture management in the correct sequential order.
questions.explanation: Priority is always Resuscitation (save life), then Restore anatomy (Reduction), Maintain position (Alignment), and Hold it there (Immobilization).
questions.hint: Save the life first, then fix the bone.

questions.question: How will you determine that a bleeding cut injury is arterial bleeding?

options.text: Oozing of blood from both ends
Bleeding gushes/spurts at the proximal end
Blood oozes slowly from the vessel

questions.explanation: Arterial bleeding is bright red and spurts/gushes with the pulse due to high pressure.
questions.hint: Think about the pressure and color.

questions.question: Which of the following is an indication for skeletal traction?
questions.explanation: Skeletal traction is often used for femoral shaft fractures in adults to maintain length and alignment against strong muscle pull.
questions.hint: Used for large long bones with strong muscles.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a complication of traction?
questions.explanation: Pressure sores, pneumonia, and nerve injury are complications of immobility/traction. Parasitic infections are unrelated.
questions.hint: One of these is an infectious disease not caused by mechanics.

questions.question: Choose the EARLY complication of compound fractures.
questions.explanation: Bleeding occurs immediately. Osteomyelitis and Union issues are later complications.
questions.hint: What happens right at the moment of injury?

questions.question: What is the aetiology of Gas Gangrene?
questions.explanation: Gas gangrene is caused by Clostridia species (anaerobes). C. tetani causes Tetanus.

questions.question: The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) entails assessment of which responses? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: GCS components are Eye opening, Verbal response, and Motor response.

questions.question: Which statement about Osteoporosis is correct?

options.text: It is an uncommon cause of fragility fractures
Hormonal therapy plays a role in treatment

questions.explanation: Osteoporosis involves decreased density. It is common in post-menopausal women and treated with HRT/bisphosphonates.

questions.question: The most common site for pressure sore in a sitting/wheelchair patient is:
questions.explanation: When sitting, weight is borne on the ischial tuberosities.

questions.question: Which statement is correct regarding second degree burns?

options.text: Only very superficial epidermis is affected
Are commonly caused by hot fluids (scalds)

questions.explanation: Scalds typically cause partial thickness (2nd degree) burns with blistering.

questions.question: Which response concerning skin grafting is correct?

options.text: Use powerful antiseptics on donor site
The donor can be the patient himself (Autograft)
Full thickness grafts involve removing epidermis only

questions.explanation: Autografts (patient's own skin) are the standard for permanent coverage.

questions.question: A burn patient develops epigastric pain and hematemesis. Diagnose the condition.
questions.explanation: Curling's ulcers are stress ulcers associated with severe burns. (Cushing's are associated with head injury).

questions.question: Determine the correct response regarding Lipoma.
questions.explanation: Lipomas are benign tumors of adipose (fat) tissue.

questions.question: A patient presents with black wet toes and RBS of 13.0 mmol/l. Diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Hyperglycemia + Gangrene = Diabetic Foot Complication.

questions.question: Formulate the correct Wagner's classification for a patient with gangrene of two toes (part of foot).
questions.explanation: Wagner Grade 4 is gangrene of forefoot/toes. Grade 5 is whole foot.

questions.question: Progressive dysphagia first to solids then liquids suggests:
questions.explanation: Progressive mechanical obstruction is hallmark of esophageal cancer.
questions.hint: Solids get stuck first, then liquids.

questions.question: Mallory Weiss syndrome typically presents with:
questions.explanation: Mucosal tear at GE junction causing upper GI bleed.

questions.question: Infantile Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis typically presents with:
questions.explanation: Classic presentation is non-bilious projectile vomiting in a 2-8 week old male.

questions.question: Flail chest presents with:

options.text: It is rarely a surgical emergency

questions.explanation: Segment moves opposite to chest wall during respiration.

questions.question: Predict the correct explanation regarding colostomy.

options.text: It is indicated in colorectal cancer

questions.explanation: Colostomy is bringing colon to skin, often for obstruction/cancer.

questions.question: Determine the correct description of a hydrocele.

options.text: Collection of fluid between layers of tunica vaginalis

questions.explanation: Fluid accumulation around the testis in the tunica vaginalis.

questions.question: Which statement correctly describes strangulated hernias?

options.text: Direct inguinal are common in females
They present with vomiting, distension and are irreducible

questions.explanation: Strangulation causes obstruction (vomiting) and ischemia. They cannot be reduced.
questions.hint: It's stuck and blocking the gut.

questions.question: Predict general causes of hematuria. (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Hematuria can be caused by Stones, Trauma, Tumors, and Clotting disorders.

questions.question: Which statement describes the clinical presentation of Colles' fracture?

options.text: Fracture of radius with volar displacement

questions.explanation: Dorsal displacement of distal radius creates the 'Dinner Fork' shape.

questions.question: Formulate appropriate management for Choledocholithiasis.

options.text: Ultrasound, bilirubin levels, surgery/ERCP and antibiotics

questions.explanation: Stones in the CBD need removal (Surgery/ERCP) and infection control.

questions.question: What is the treatment of choice for anal rectal abscesses?
questions.explanation: Pus must be drained.

questions.question: Herniotomy is a procedure commonly performed for:
questions.explanation: Herniotomy (removal of sac) is usually sufficient for congenital hernias in children.
questions.hint: Kids just need the sac removed.

questions.question: Determine X-ray features of chronic osteomyelitis.
questions.explanation: Sequestrum (dead bone) and Involucrum (new bone) are hallmarks.

questions.question: Advice on appropriate IMMEDIATE management of tension pneumothorax.
questions.explanation: Immediate needle decompression converts tension to simple pneumothorax before chest tube.

questions.question: 'Bone is strengthened along lines of weakness' (Wolff's Law). Which stage of healing does this describe?
questions.explanation: Remodeling is the final stage where bone reshapes according to stress.

questions.question: Specific surgical management for dog bites:
questions.explanation: Debridement is key. Primary suturing is avoided due to infection risk.
questions.hint: Clean it out, don't sew it up.

questions.question: 'Tophus' is the pathognomonic lesion in:
questions.explanation: Tophi are uric acid crystal deposits seen in Gout.

questions.question: Which feature is NOT correct about rickets?
questions.explanation: Sunburst appearance is seen in Osteosarcoma, not rickets.

questions.question: Select the precautions to avoid transfusion overload. (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Precautions include diuretics, slow rate, monitoring, and positioning.
questions.hint: Slow down and remove excess fluid.

questions.question: Match the degree of hemorrhoids to its clinical feature.
questions.explanation: Classification is based on prolapse and reducibility.

questions.question: Case Study: 40yo female, yellow eyes/mucous membranes, severe pruritus, pale stools. Diagnosis: Obstructive Jaundice. Select relevant management steps. (Select all that apply)

richContent.content: Patient Case: 40-year-old female. 2 months history of Jaundice + Severe Pruritus + Pale Stools.

options.text: Liver Function Tests (expect high Conjugated Bilirubin/ALP)

questions.explanation: The case describes Obstructive Jaundice. Requires investigation of biliary tree and correction of clotting (Vit K) before intervention.
